Academics, learning, and just generally being considered a smart person were all very important to me and I feared I had lost all of that.

My parents noticed I wasn‚Äôt ok. I told them that I was afraid I had brain damage. My dad who is a psychiatrist told me that it was probably due to a med change and a family friend who‚Äôs a nurse said her patients frequently used the same drugs as I had, assuring me that I would be fine. I would slowly get back to normal over the next few weeks. I should stop perseverating, it was just health anxiety.

In the next few days, as time went on and I didn‚Äôt notice my functioning returning, I shifted from a deep fear to a deep despair. When I told my parents the reason why, they attributed my low functioning to my mood, not my mood to my functioning. They wouldn‚Äôt even consider that I had brain damage. I really wanted to believe that they were right; that this was a typical and impermanent drop in mood associated with my mental health condition that was impacting my cognitive abilities. They told me to schedule an appointment with my psychiatrist to get a med change.

By that time, the start of my next semester of college was approaching. I really thought about staying home because I worried I wasn‚Äôt capable of doing classwork. I told my parents and they once again assured me that I was fine and hadn‚Äôt suffered brain damage. Although I‚Äôm not really sure why, I ended up returning. Maybe I thought a change of scenery would help.

A few weeks in, I was really feeling how much my cognition had slowed down. My college was considered prestigious and I was a philosophy major, making my coursework relatively demanding. I just couldn‚Äôt keep up. I started grasping at straws for any explanation as to why this wasn't permanent. Maybe it was because I had quit nicotine, maybe changing the allergy medicine I regularly take could alleviate this. Nothing worked.

At this point I was so withdrawn and hopeless I stopped seeing my friends and leaving my room except to attend class and grab food at the dining hall. I sent my mom a text telling her that the reason I‚Äôd been so depressed was because of having brain damage. Instead of accepting what I told her, she said she was sorry I felt that way, told me to schedule another appointment with my psychiatrist, and scheduled a flight to come out and meet me.

When she got there, she tried to get me out to take my mind off things. She took me on a hike. On the ride out there, I reiterated what I thought was happening to me. She compared it to the delusions I had when I was psychotic; that my mood was responsible for why I thought that. At the end of the hike, I told her I had begun keeping a journal of positive memories so that I had something for the people I love to remember after I kill myself. She held on to me and we cried. When we got back, I packed up my dorm room so that I could return home early.

When I got home, I attended a php/iop program. I got my meds changed and spent a lot of time in groups, but nothing worked. There‚Äôs no combination of words I can say or therapeutic modality I can implement that could return me to the level of functioning I was at before. I ‚Äúgraduated‚Äù the program when our insurance stopped covering it. At this point I kind of stopped talking about brain damage specifically. I would say things like ‚Äúbrain fog‚Äù and talk about how I felt like I didn‚Äôt have the same capacities, but I wouldn‚Äôt attribute it. It became obfuscated.
By now, Christmas time had come around. I celebrated with my family but felt numb and hopeless through it. Every positive moment was clouded by it.

Days sort of just faded into each other at this point. I wasn‚Äôt working, I wasn‚Äôt in school, and I had no social network. I started drinking. Not every night, but I would overdo it when I did. It was the only time I didn‚Äôt feel terrible. I was still suicidal and had written and crumpled up multiple notes. The only reason I was still alive was because I wanted to stay here for the people I loved and felt like I hadn‚Äôt written enough stuff to leave behind to give my family closure. This might sound like a lighthearted way of putting it given the stakes, but I didn‚Äôt want to leave them hanging.

One night, when I was particularly down, I told my parents that I wanted to kill myself. They tried to reassure me that I had an important voice and so many reasons to live. My mom started hyperventilating and silently cried. After that night, they decided that it would be good for me to go back into treatment. This time they found a really expensive one out of town and sent me there. I wanted to go, too, although I didn‚Äôt have much hope for it actually making me better.

While I was there, I genuinely was in a better mood than I had been for the past year or so. There were a lot of really good people that I met and socialized for the first time in forever. Still, after I left the clinic and went back to where I was staying, I would go back into the same headspace I had always been in. I would become deeply hopeless and suicidal. At this point, I also began perseverating on how this could have been avoided or gone differently. There hasn‚Äôt been a night of going to bed in the last year where I haven‚Äôt thought about the fact that I have brain damage and that things could have gone differently for me. I miss when I could just go to bed.

When my time at the program wrapped up, I did feel like I got a bit out of it this time. I had at least gotten better with executive functioning and identified that I needed to have community to feel ok at times. Still, I felt like I had wasted a lot of my parents money for what was effectively palliative care; it felt as though I was terminal and any interventions were only effective as far as they could numb the pain.

When I got home, I didn‚Äôt immediately regress and I have been doing better. I have more moments where I feel ok and was able to enroll at a community college to try to maybe make something of myself again. Still, there has not been a day that‚Äôs gone by where I haven‚Äôt thought about killing myself, the fact that I have brain damage, and the ways that this all didn‚Äôt need to happen.

I‚Äôm wrapping up my first semester now and have submitted applications to transfer. Despite this, I don‚Äôt have any confidence in my ability to succeed academically. Even if I can do my work well enough now, I worry that they‚Äôll be a point where I hit a wall, won‚Äôt be able to continue my education because of my now limited capacities, and will have to drop out and go through all of this again.

I haven‚Äôt really talked to anyone about having brain damage despite the fact that it‚Äôs impacting my mood so heavily. It just sort of faded as something I talked about since hearing my parents reassure me that I was fine when I knew I wasn‚Äôt became less and less helpful. I don‚Äôt know if they still think about it at all or consider it as a possibility. My dad has brought up that he thought a med I was on could be impacting me and said it felt like he had lost his daughter. Hearing that broke my heart. Still, they say things that indicate that they‚Äôve completely forgotten about it; that I‚Äôm a good writer; that I have an important voice in philosophy; that I‚Äôm one of the smartest people that they‚Äôve met. Hearing it isn‚Äôt helpful and doesn‚Äôt make me feel any better. It just reminds me of how much I‚Äôve lost and how much I‚Äôve blown my potential.

I don‚Äôt really know what my next steps are. I think I might have the capacity to put together a semi-decent life if I tried hard enough, but I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs worth it. We‚Äôve thrown four different medications and probably over 100,000 dollars in treatment at it and it hasn‚Äôt gotten much better. Really it just breaks my heart.
